newsitem.title: ITALY: Bossi hopes to breathe life into Italy's League.
newsitem.headline: Bossi hopes to breathe life into Italy's League.

text.p: Firebrand leader Umberto Bossi will try to breathe new life into Italy's flagging Northern League when he pitches for endorsement of his separatist agenda at a party congress this weekend.
But many wonder whether the man who has been the scourge of Italy's south, which he calls corrupt and mafia-ridden, has lost his touch.

The League, which rose to prominence on a wave of public disgust with political corruption, won a solid eight percent of votes at a general election last April on a federalist platform built to appeal to Italians in the affluent north.
But a declaration of independence for the movement's self-styled northern "republic of Padania" fell flat last September, suggesting Bossi had misjudged the popular mood.

"The political leadership is in trouble and there is no great sense of initiative," said political commentator Gianfranco Pasquino. "They have not recovered from the September (independence) declaration which was a failure."
Since then Bossi, a master at grabbing headlines, has found it a struggle to draw media attention. His attempts to seize the initiative have either flopped or made only a small ripple.
The League made an abortive attempt in October to frustrate passage of the 1997 budget by presenting 1,800 amendments.

Last week the party pulled out of a new parliamentary commission on constitutional reform because the body was not prepared to give its proposals to split the country a hearing. The commission will go ahead regardless.
Nonetheless Bossi's verbal barbs against the political establishment in Rome have lost none of their sting.

"I would be wary of saying the League is in decline," said Renato Mannheimer, a polling expert based in Milan. "Bossi's style is to make sure he appears in the papers and to show he is different. He then reaps the benefit at election time."
Bossi continues to play on deep-seated resentment in the north, particularly among the self-employed, with high taxes, inefficient social services and a remote bureacracy in Rome.

Asked in a recent newspaper interview whether he intended to invite representatives of Italy's other major political parties to the three-day League congress, which opens in Milan on Friday, Bossi gave a characteristically scathing reply.
"Invite the leaders of the other parties? For the love of God they are Italians. If they were to come we would have to watch our wallets," Bossi told Milan's Corriere della Sera.
He said he is sticking unswervingly to his separatist message, which he embraced last year after ditching federalism.
"I am in no doubt that independence will save Padania and will also save the south," said Bossi.
Irene Pivetti, a former leader of the movement who was expelled last year for dissent, said she believed Bossi's decision to adopt the cause of separatism had sealed his fate.
"The beginning of the end for Bossi has been the decision to pursue secession," said Pivetti, who served as speaker of the lower house of parliament from 1994 to 1996.
But so long as Italy's main political parties failed to reform the country's creaking state machinery there was space for Bossi to make political capital, Pivetti said.
"From his point of view there is room (to manoeuvre). As long as the state is not reformed there is room," Pivetti told Reuters.
